title: Gravitational-wave signatures of gravito-electromagnetic couplings
authors:
Theodoros Papanikolaou, Charalampos Tzerefos, Salvatore Capozziello,
  Gaetano Lambiase
abstract:
Gravitational waves (GWs) can undoubtedly serve as a messenger from the early
Universe acting as well as a novel probe of the underlying gravity theory. In
this work, motivated by one-loop vacuum-polarization effects on curved
spacetime, we investigate a gravitational theory with non-minimal
curvature-electromagnetic coupling terms of the form $\xi R
F_{\mu\nu}F^{\mu\nu}$, where $R$ is the scalar curvature and $F_{\mu\nu}$ the
Faraday tensor, which can be responsible for the generation of primordial
electromagnetic fields. We study then the GW signatures of such coupling terms
deriving in particular for the first time to the best of our knowledge the
modified tensor modes equation of motion. Remarkably, we find a universal
infrared (IR) frequency scaling $f^5$ of the electromagnetically induced GW
(EMIGW) signal, which, depending on the energy scale of inflation, the duration
of inflation and reheating as well as the dynamical behaviour of the gauge
coupling function $\xi$, can be well within the detection sensitivity bands of
GW experiments such as SKA, LISA, ET and BBO, being thus potentially detectable
in the future by GW observatories.
